Rule Description: Checks if a response contains a first-person opinionated phrase based on the list in the card
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Revise your work. The bolded phrase expresses an opinion. Instead, focus your response on ideas your read in the text.
Feedback - V2: Revise your work. The bolded phrase expresses an opinion. Instead, focus your response on ideas your read in the text.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding First-Person to Maintain an Objective Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding First-Person to Maintain an Objective Tone

Rule Description: Checks to see if the first word is a verb (ignore gerunds and participles) and asks students to add a subject. Some exceptions apply for "so" responses (see card for info)
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Revise your work. Instead of starting your response with an action word, start with a person, place, or thing.
Feedback - V2: Revise your work. Instead of starting your response with an action word, start with a person, place, or thing.
Combined Concept: Structure | Simple, Compound, & Complex Sentences | Joining Sentences

Rule Description: Uses SpaCy to identify when "so" responses begin with the base form of a verb indicating an opinion
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
Clear your response and try again. Giving a command works well in persuasive writing, but here the goal is to complete the sentence with a fact from the text. 

Instead of using "so" to give a command, use it to show a result or consequence. Try starting your response with the name of a person, group, or thing.
Feedback - V2:
Rewrite your response. Your response gives a command. That often works well in persuasive writing, but in this activity the goal is to express an idea or fact from the text.

Instead of starting with an action word, try starting your response with the name of a person, group, or thing from the text instead.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Imperatives to Maintain an Objective Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Imperatives to Maintain an Objective Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains an opinionated phrase based on the linked list
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Revise your work. The bolded phrase expresses an opinion. Instead, focus your response on ideas you read in the text.
Feedback - V2: Revise your work. The bolded phrase expresses an opinion. Instead, focus your response on ideas you read in the text.
Bolding?: Bold the entire phrase. If the rule identifies part of a word (e.g., s important), the whole phrase should be bolded (e.g. is important)
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Opinionated Phrases to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Opinionated Phrases to Maintain an Academic Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains "should" in the first subject/verb pair, indicating an opinion.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
For this activity, avoid giving your own opinion, feelings, or suggestions. 

Rewrite your response without the word "should," and make sure your response only includes ideas from the text.
Feedback - V2: Remember, for this activity, avoid giving your opinion—your thoughts, feelings, or suggestions. Rewrite your response without the word should, and make sure that your response expresses an idea from the text.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Should to Maintain an Objective Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Should to Maintain an Objective Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains "must" in the first subject/verb pair, indicating an opinion.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
For this activity, avoid giving your own opinion, feelings, or suggestions. 

Rewrite your response without the word "must," and make sure your response only includes ideas from the text.
Feedback - V2: Remember, for this activity, avoid giving your opinion—your thoughts, feelings, or suggestions. Rewrite your response without the word must, and make sure that your response expresses an idea from the text.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Must to Maintain an Objective Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Must to Maintain an Objective Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains "need" in the first subject/verb pair, indicating an opinion.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
For this activity, avoid giving your own opinion, feelings, or suggestions. 

Rewrite your response without the word "need," and make sure your response only includes ideas from the text.
Feedback - V2: Remember, for this activity, avoid giving your opinion—your thoughts, feelings, or suggestions. Rewrite your response without the word need, and make sure that your response expresses an idea from the text.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Need to Maintain an Objective Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Need to Maintain an Objective Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains "ought" in the first subject/verb pair, indicating an opinion.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
For this activity, avoid giving your own opinion, feelings, or suggestions. 

Rewrite your response without the word "ought," and make sure your response only includes ideas from the text.
Feedback - V2: Remember, for this activity, avoid giving your opinion—your thoughts, feelings, or suggestions. Rewrite your response without the word ought and make sure that your response expresses an idea from the text.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Ought to Maintain an Objective Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Ought to Maintain an Objective Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains a first-person reference based on the list in the card
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
Words like "I," "me," and "us" are used to express your own point of view. For this activity, focus on the ideas in the text instead. 

Rewrite your response without the bolded word, and make sure your response only includes ideas from the text.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding First-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding First-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains a second-person reference based on the list in the card
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
"You" and "your" are often used to talk directly to the reader. In this activity, the goal is to complete the sentence with facts from the text. 

Rewrite your response without "you" or "your," and focus your response on an idea from the text.
Feedback - V2: Revise your work. You and your are often used to talk directly to the reader. To make your writing more formal, rewrite your response without using you or your.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Second-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone
Notes for Feedback: Note that this may lead student to writing an imperative with an implied subject instead.
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Second-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response uses the word "please"
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
"Please" is often used when you're asking your reader to do something. In this activity, the goal is to complete the sentence with facts from the text. 

Rewrite your response without the word "please," and focus your response on an idea from the text.
Feedback - V2: Please is often used when you're asking your reader to do something. In formal writing, you should avoid speaking to your reader directly. Rewrite your response without using the word please to make your writing more formal.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Please to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Please to Maintain an Academic Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response uses the word "maybe"
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
"Maybe" is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something. Here, the goal is to use facts from the text instead of giving your own opinion.

Rewrite your response without using the word "maybe," and be sure your response only includes ideas from the text.
Feedback - V2: Maybe is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something. Rewrite your response without using the word maybe to make your writing more formal and confident.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Maybe to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Maybe to Maintain an Academic Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response uses the word "perhaps"
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
"Perhaps" is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something. Here, the goal is to use facts from the text instead of giving your own opinion.

Rewrite your response without using the word "perhaps," and be sure your response only includes ideas from the text.
Feedback - V2: Perhaps is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something. Rewrite your response without using the word perhaps to make your writing more formal and confident.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Perhaps to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Perhaps to Maintain an Academic Tone

Rule Description: Identifies when an entire response is written in capital letters.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Clear your response and try again. Instead of using all capital letters, only capitalize the first letter of proper names.
Feedback - V2: Rewrite your sentence. Instead of using all capital letters, only capitalize the first letter of proper names.
Combined Concept: Capitalization | Capitalization | Using Sentence Case
Notes for Feedback: Rewrite your sentence. Instead of using all capital letters, only capitalize the first letter of proper names.

Rule Description: Identifies when a response has a duplicated word. This should ignore when the conjunction is duplicated. Does not recognize repeated phrases.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Now remove one of the repeated words.
Feedback - V2: Now remove one of the repeated words.
Bolding?: Bold both occurences of the repeated word
Combined Concept: Structure | Sentence Quality | Avoiding Repeated Words

Rule Description: Identifies if the conjunction is duplicated.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Remove the bolded word. Since it's already in the provided part of the sentence, you don't need to write it again.
Feedback - V2: Remove the bolded word. Since it's already in the provided part of the sentence, you don't need to write it again.
Bolding?: Bold the duplicated conjunction (and the conjunction in the stem, if possible)
Combined Concept: Activity Guidelines | Comprehension Activity Guidelines | Using a Single Joining Word
Notes: Not developed yet. Front-end only for now. Convert to back-end in the future.

Rule Description: Identifies incorrect subject pronouns (e.g. object pronouns, such as "me", possessive determiners such as "my" or possessive pronouns such as "mine").
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. Use "he," "she," or "they" instead.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. Use he, she, or they instead.
Combined Concept: Nouns & Pronouns | Subject Pronouns | Subject Pronouns
Notes for Feedback: This has to be really vague/not very instructive because it's too difficult to explain what a subject looks like without knowing the specific context (as in, it can be the person or thing doing the action, being described, having an action done to them in a passive sentence, etc.)

Rule Description: Identifies sentences where a singular determiner (a, an) has as its head a plural noun.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Check your work. Only use "a" or "an" before a singular word. Update the bolded words by removing "a" or "an" or by making the word singular instead.
Feedback - V2: Check your work. Only use a or an before a singular word. Update the bolded words by removing a or an or by making the word singular instead.
Bolding?: Not only the article, but also the noun
Combined Concept: Articles | Articles | Articles
Notes for Feedback: Note: Depending on the context, the student may need to remove the determiner or make the noun singular.

Rule: Plural versus possessive nouns - Possessive Noun Optimal
Rule Description: Identifies when a plural is used instead of a possessive
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. Add an apostrophe so it shows ownership.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. Add an apostrophe so it shows ownership.
Combined Concept: Nouns & Pronouns | Possessive Nouns | Plural vs. Possessive Nouns
Notes: Should Plural vs. Possessive Nouns rules should come after subject verb agreement?

Rule: Plural versus possessive nouns - Plural Noun Optimal
Rule Description: Identifies when a possessive is used instead of a plural
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. Only use an apostrophe to show ownership. When a word is plural, you don't need an apostrophe.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. Only use an apostrophe to show ownership. When a word is plural, you don't need an apostrophe.
Combined Concept: Nouns & Pronouns | Possessive Nouns | Plural vs. Possessive Nouns
Notes: Should Plural vs. Possessive Nouns rules should come after subject verb agreement?

Rule: Subject verb agreement with simple noun
Rule Description: Uses the incorrect verb with a simple noun subject
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Remember that an action word always has to match with the person or thing doing the action. Look at the bolded words and make sure they're both singular or both plural.
Feedback - V2: Remember that an action word always has to match with the person or thing doing the action. Look at the bolded words and make sure they're both singular or both plural.
Bolding?: Subject in addition to the verb
Combined Concept: Verbs | Subject Verb Agreement | Subject Verb Agreement

Rule: Subject verb agreement with personal pronoun
Rule Description: Uses the incorrect verb with a personal pronoun subject
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Now check the bolded action word. Remember, "he," "she," and "it" need to be paired with a singular action word. "They" needs a plural action word.
Feedback - V2: Now check the bolded action word. Remember, he, she, and it need to be paired with a singular action word. They needs a plural action word.
Bolding?: Subject in addition to the verb
Combined Concept: Verbs | Subject Verb Agreement | Subject Verb Agreement

Rule Description: Uses the incorrect verb when the subject comes after the verb
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Remember that an action word always has to match with the person or thing doing the action. Look at the bolded words and make sure they're both singular or both plural.
Feedback - V2: Remember that an action word always has to match with the person or thing doing the action. Look at the bolded words and make sure they're both singular or both plural.
Bolding?: Subject in addition to the verb
Combined Concept: Verbs | Subject Verb Agreement | Subject Verb Agreement

Rule: Subject verb agreement with collective noun
Rule Description: Uses the incorrect verb with a collective noun subject
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update your action word. Group words like "team" or "government" are paired with a singular action word when the people in the group are acting together as a unit. Look at both bolded words and decide whether the action word should be singular or plural.
Feedback - V2:
Update your action word. Words like team or government are singular when they act as a unit or group, which means they also need to be paired with a singular action word. When each person in the group is acting individually, the words are plural instead.
Look at both bolded words and decide whether the action word should be singular or plural.
Bolding?: Subject in addition to the verb
Combined Concept: Verbs | Subject Verb Agreement | Subject Verb Agreement

Rule: Subject verb agreement with indefinite pronoun
Rule Description: Uses the incorrect verb with an indefinite pronoun subject
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
Remember that words like "everyone" and "each" are singular, while words like "both" and "several" are plural. 

Look at both bolded words and make the action word singular or plural so the two words match.
Feedback - V2: Remember that words like everyone and each are singular, while words like both and several are plural. Look at both bolded words and make the action word singular or plural so the two words match.
Bolding?: Subject in addition to the verb
Combined Concept: Verbs | Subject Verb Agreement | Subject Verb Agreement

Rule: Subject verb agreement with separate subject and verb
Rule Description: Uses the incorrect verb when the subject and verb are separated
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]:
Remember that an action word always has to match with the person or thing doing the action, even when they're separated by other words. 

Look at the bolded words and make sure they're both singular or both plural.
Feedback - V2: Remember that an action word always has to match with the person or thing doing the action, even when they're separated by other words. Look at the bolded words and make sure they're both singular or both plural.
Bolding?: Subject in addition to the verb
Combined Concept: Verbs | Subject Verb Agreement | Subject Verb Agreement

Rule Description: Identifies when a student has written a contraction without an apostrophe (e.g., wasnt). Does not reocgnize when a student misuses the apostrophe.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Now add an apostrophe to the bolded word to show that a letter was left out.
Feedback - V2: Now add an apostrophe to the bolded word to show that a letter was left out.
Bolding?: Not only final token, but full verb
Combined Concept: Contractions | Contractions | Contractions
Notes for Feedback: We may want to use keywords later if data shows students are frequently putting the apostrophe in the wrong place after getting this feedback.

Rule Description: Checks if a sentence ends in a valid punctuation mark (period or question mark).
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Good work! Now add a period to the end of your sentence.
Feedback - V2: Good work! Now add a period to the end of your sentence.
Combined Concept: Punctuation | End Punctuation | Ending Periods

Rule Description: Identifies punctuation that is not followed by a space or that is incorrectly preceded by a space.
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Check your spacing. You may need to add or remove spaces around your punctuation.
Feedback - V2: Check your spacing. You may need to add or remove spaces around your punctuation.
Combined Concept: Punctuation | Spaces with Punctuation | Spaces with Punctuation
Notes for Feedback: What punctuation is included in this? No to dashes. Yes to open brackets.

Rule Description: Identifies when a response uses "an" instead of "a" before a consonant
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Check your work. Only use an before words that start with a vowel like a, e, i, o, or u. Use a before all other words.
Feedback - V2: Check your work. Only use an before words that start with a, e, i, o, or u. Use a before all other words.
Bolding?: Bold "an" and the next word or noun phrase
Combined Concept: Articles | Indefinite Articles | A vs An

Rule Description: Identifies when a response uses "a" instead of "an" before a vowel
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Check your work. Use "an" before words that start with a vowel like a, e, i, o, or u.
Feedback - V2: Check your work. Use an before words that start with a vowel like a, e, i, o, or u.
Bolding?: Bold "a" and the next word or noun phrase
Combined Concept: Articles | Indefinite Articles | A vs An

Rule Description: Identifies when "it's" is used instead of "its"
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. When "its" shows ownership, you don't need an apostrophe.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. When its shows ownership, you don't need an apostrophe.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | It's, Its | Its

Rule Description: Identifies when "its" is used instead of "it's"
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Now add a missing apostrophe to the bolded word. Use an apostrophe in "it's" when you mean "it is."
Feedback - V2: Now add a missing apostrophe to the bolded word. Use an apostrophe in it's when you mean it is.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | It's, Its | It's

Rule: Their vs. there vs. they're - They're Optimal
Rule Description: Identifies when a student uses there or their instead of they're
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. "There" is used for locations. "They're" means they are. "Their " is used to show ownership.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. There is used for locations. They're is the same as they are. Their is used to show ownership.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | There, They're, Their | They're

Rule: Their vs. there vs. they're - There Optimal
Rule Description: Identifies when a student uses their or they're instead of there
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. "There" is used for locations. "They're" means they are. "Their " is used to show ownership.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. There is used for locations. They're is the same as they are. Their is used to show ownership.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | There, They're, Their | There

Rule: Their vs. there vs. they're - Their Optimal
Rule Description: Identifies when a student uses there or they're instead of their
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. "There" is used for locations. "They're" means they are. "Their " is used to show ownership.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. There is used for locations. They're is the same as they are. Their is used to show ownership.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | There, They're, Their | Their

Rule Description: Identifies instances of "then" that should be "than".
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. "Then" is used for time. "Than" is used to make a comparison.
Feedback - V2: Check your work. Then is used for time. Than is used to make a comparison.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | Than, Then | Than

Rule Description: Identifies instances of "than" that should be "then".
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. "Then" is used for time. "Than" is used to make a comparison.
Feedback - V2: Check your work. Then is used for time. Than is used to make a comparison.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | Than, Then | Then

Rule Description: Identifies when a student uses the word persons instead of people
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. If you're talking about more than one person, use "people." Use "person's" to show ownership.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. If you're talking about more than one person, use people. If you're talking about something that belongs to a person, use person's.
Combined Concept: Nouns & Pronouns | Irregular Plural Nouns | People

Rule Description: Identifies when a student incorrectly uses peoples'
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. If you're talking about something that belongs to people, use "people's."
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. If you're talking about something that belongs to people, use people's.
Combined Concept: Nouns & Pronouns | Possessive Nouns | Plural Possessive Nouns

Rule Description: Uses peoples instead of people
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. When talking about more than one person, use "people."
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. When talking about more than one person, use people.
Combined Concept: Nouns & Pronouns | Irregular Plural Nouns | People

Rule Description: Uses monies instead of money
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded word. Use "money" instead.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. Use money instead.
Combined Concept: Nouns & Pronouns | Irregular Plural Nouns | Irregular Plural Nouns Ending in Y
Level 0 Concept: Irregular Plural Nouns Ending in Y

Rule Description: Uses in regards to instead of in regard to
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the bolded phrase by removing the "s" from "regards."
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded phrase. Use in regard to without an s.
Combined Concept: Commonly Confused Words | In Regard To, In Regards To | In Regards To
Level 1 Concept: In Regard To, In Regards To

Rule Description: Uses gasses instead of gases
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Update the spelling of the bolded word. Use "gases" when talking about more than one gas.
Feedback - V2: Update the bolded word. Use gases when talking about more than one gas.
Combined Concept: Spelling | Spelling | Spelling

Rule Description: Identifies when a student incorrectly uses an apostrophe in a decade (e.g., 1990's)
Feedback V3 [HM 4/21]: Now delete the apostrophe in the bolded decade to make it plural.
Feedback - V2: Now delete the apostrophe in the bolded decade to make it plural.
Combined Concept: Punctuation | Apostrophes in Dates | Apostrophes in Dates
